It has been brought to our attention that there is intimidation that is going on.  Some of the applicants have complained of being abused, some of the victims have been complaining of having been threatened.  I want to make it clear that none of this will be tolerated.
	Whilst we do understand the background to this hearing in particular, that people lost their lives, their property, but let us not give anyone the right to intimidate anyone or to hurl any abuse at anyone. I therefore urge everyone of you to co-operate.
	The proceedings have been jogging for a long time and therefore I urge each one of you to please co-operate so that we can proceed with these hearings to finality.  I also hope that your respective legal representatives have conveyed to you what I am now repeating to you.  Thank you.
	Mr Baloyi, may I remind you that you are still under oath.
Mr Baloyi, you've been living in Boipatong for forty five years.  From your testimony it sounds as if you are one of the community leaders, is that correct?
And you're also a leader in your church.
To which political party do you belong, Mr Baloyi, if any?  I'll repeat the question.  To which political party do you belong, if any?
I was a leader of Shangaans in the Vaal area at the time when the Gazankulu homelands was in existence, from this area, including Sebokeng.
What I'm referring to is say from 1990.
I was not politically affiliated to any political organisation.
Are you aware of it that the IFP was chased out of Boipatong?  People belonging to the IFP or who were supporters of the IFP had trouble living in Boipatong.
It did appear as if there was conflict, but I cannot speak on their behalf.
But as a community leader at least you knew what was going on in Boipatong, is that true?
It was clear that there were conflicts.  There was conflict between the ANC and the IFP.
And this conflict resulted that the IFP members and supporters could not live safely in Boipatong, is that true?
Yes, I think so, but it did not start there.  That was did not start there.
What do you mean by that?
I mean that there was this conflict because they felt that the ANC should not be dominant in the area, they wanted to be the dominant party.
But the question is, that as a result of this conflict the IFP members and supporters could not live safely in Boipatong, is that so?  It's easy, you must just tell us yes or no.
From 1990 until the night of the attack, were any of the IFP members that you are aware of, necklaced in Boipatong?
No, I did not hear of anybody being necklaced.  The only person that I know of was one who was burnt ...(intervention)
That's what I mean, I'm sorry.  You did hear of a person being burnt?
Yes, I did hear of that.
And that person was an IFP member or a supporter.
I am not certain whether he was a member or supporter, but yes, he was in the IFP fold.
Do you know of any houses that were burnt down in Boipatong, that belonged to IFP members or IFP supporters?

The one that I'm well aware of is the one belonging to Mtwana Zulu, but there were other houses that were burnt, the house belonging to people who were just supporters of the IFP, but not full members.
So their houses were burnt.  Do you know how many?
No, I did not keep count, unless if I were to check from the book.
So it was quite a lot?
Quite a few but not too many.
The trenches that were dug in the street, which you helped to dig, was that then - the barricades that were erected, was that also to keep out IFP members from Boipatong?
Chairperson, I'm not sure if the evidence was that Mr Baloyi actually dug trenches.
I thought the question was the trenches that were dug.
I did say which he helped to dig.  I thought he said so yesterday.  I'll retract it and I'll rephrase.
Mr Baloyi, you did testify that, as far as I recall, yes.
Yes, he did.  These trenches were also dug to keep out not only the police, but also the IFP members, is that correct?
IFP people did not use Koyocos, they walked on foot.  Those trenches were dug to prevent police vehicles from moving about in the area.
And the comrades, were they appointed to keep out IFP members from the area?
No, they were not instructed to do so.  Even now they are able to walk there freely, nothing happens to them.

I know now they are able to walk there freely, I know because we've been there, I've seen IFP members in Boipatong, but I'm speaking about the year or the two years prior to that attack.  Because there has been evidence to this Committee by the attackers, that it was not safe to go to Boipatong for them at all.  They could not go and buy food there, their children couldn't go to school there.  Would you agree or what would you say about that?
The children were able to go to school.  It was them who were fighting the people of Boipatong, and that is why they were afraid of entering the township.
So the comrades saw to it that the IFP members did not come into the township, is that correct?
We used to live amongst them, I mean IFP members in the township.

Mr Baloyi, I don't think you're answering the question, the question is, that after 1990, 1991 up to 1992 until the attack when the houses were burnt and people were, the one person that you know of was burnt, it was not safe for IFP members to come to Boipatong and the comrades were there to keep them out.  Do you agree or disagree with that statement?
I do not agree with that.
So they could come freely to Boipatong, IFP members and supporters?
Those people who were afraid of coming to the township were those who were involved in the fighting with the residents of Boipatong.  Nobody prevented or stopped them from coming into the township.
Why was Mtwana Zulu's house burnt?
He had a fight with somebody else.  Nobody would have just gone out to burn his house for nothing.  Mtwana was a respectable person, he did not trouble anyone.
But he was a leader of the IFP.
Yes, he was, but he did not trouble anyone.
And that could be the reason for burning his house?
He is the one who can explain that.  Maybe he had a fight with someone on Majola Street.
Are you aware of it that from 1990 until 1992, that the South African Police went to Kwamadala Hostel several times to search Kwamadala Hostel?
I do not reside at Kwamadala, I cannot know about what happens there.

Well I'm putting it to you that that is what happened.  Apart from you, you said yesterday you don't hate anybody, but was there a feeling of hatred between the ANC members and the IFP members in Boipatong?
The ANC is a big organisation, it is not a two people affair.  So they hated the organisation as such.

I am just saying that the ANC is a big organisation.  If two or three people within the organisation hates some other persons, you cannot claim that the entire organisation hates the IFP.  There was no trouble between us.
The problem was they tried to kill some people in the township, those people that they'd been involved in some conflict with.
So there was trouble in 1992 between the ANC and the IFP in the township, you would agree to that?
Yes, we were attacked and killed as ANC members.
That is before the attack I'm talking of, Mr Baloyi.  There was trouble in the township between IFP and ANC members.
There may have been problems that they may have to negotiate and solve.  I cannot comment on that.
Mr Baloyi, the people from Kwamadala Hostel, were they mostly IFP members, do you know?

You would not be in a position to know about people who stayed in the hostel because it was not near the township.  The people who resided at Kwamadala were mixed, some were ANC, some were IFP because they were all employees of Iscor.

When Father Patrick phoned you that night, that afternoon, why did he phone you, what did he tell you?  He said there's an imminent attack, but what did he want you to do, why did he phone you specifically?

He should have called me, he liked me.  He a priest, he was involved in God's work and he was interested in the safety of all people.  He called me so that I could also try and take safety precautions.
What did he tell you to do?
He said I should be on the alert because there was an attack that was to be launched, nothing else.
He did not tell you to warn the other people in your street or other members of your church?
Because he called in the afternoon I only informed my family, I did not go out.

Why not, Mr Baloyi?  It sounds so improbable that if you get a warning that you're going to be attacked, that you'll keep it to yourself, only warn your family to be on the alert and leave all your neighbours.
I may have told a few people, but if I told five people, it doesn't account for the rest of the neighbourhood.  Yes, there were a few people that I told.
Who did you tell, Mr Baloyi?
But I would like the five people's names.

I cannot give you their names, because I did not enquire from them when I told them this information, they are just members of the congregation.  Maybe if Father Patrick testifies you can pose questions to him.
But how did you tell these five people, did you go and see them, did you call them, what did you do?  How did you tell them?
Yes, I did call them on the phone, but I was not specifically telling them about the attack, I just warned them about the possibility.
But if you phoned them, surely you can remember at least one name.
I have children.  Do you want my children's names?

I want to know the people, the other people that were not of your family, the members of the congregation you've just told this Committee that you phoned, I would like one of their names.  Preferably all of them, but apparently you can't remember them.  Can you give us just one name?
It was not just one person that I called, I called Shirley, Lizzie and Elizabeth, Betty.  I don't know why you want this information.  I just called those people.  These people are not the attackers.
Can you give me their surnames, Mr Baloyi?
Would you please give me the names again, you said it's Shirley ...?
I called Shirley, Lizzie Tsotetsi, Gertrude Mbele, Joseph Mbele.
What is Shirley's surname, Mr Baloyi?
And Betty and Lizzie, are they also Tsotetsi?
Do the Tsotetsis all live in the same house?
And Gertrude and Joseph Mbele as well, they live in another house?
Yes, they lived in one house.
Why did you tell me a minute ago you can't remember their names, because now you remember their names and their surnames, Mr Baloyi.

It was not important, it is not important because if you telephone a person you do not really concentrate on their name.
	I am here to testify about what I witnessed, not anything else.  I thought you're going to question me on what I witnessed, not about the telephone calls that I made, no.

Mr Baloyi, just answer the questions.  I'm sure your lawyer and advocate and the Chairperson will stop me if they feel I'm asking you questions that I should not ask you.  So just answer the questions.
	Was this the first time you had been warned about an imminent attack?
I do have motor vehicles, not just one.
Why didn't you leave Boipatong that night if you ...
I do as I please, I cannot be forced to do something.

Is it not so that you did not regard this warning as serious?  And that is the reason why you did not warn your neighbours and other people of the    congregation and why you did not send your family away.
Do you want me to respond?

I do not know where I would take my children because I did not know exactly where the attackers were going to launch the attack.  If I had taken them somewhere it could have been that that is where they are going to be attacked.  Even if I was to inform other people from the streets, it would also have been, it would not have worked because I was not sure where these attackers would come from.
Is that the reason you did not warn the people in your street?
I did inform some people, that was enough.  They were also going to inform others.
The question is, is that the reason that you did not think it was going to be in Boipatong, that you did not warn the people in your street?
But he did inform some people and warn some people in his street.  He said that twice.

He did not say it was in his street, Mr Chairperson.  I'm sorry if I'm wrong.
	Is that the reason you did not warn the people in your street, Mr Baloyi? - because you did not take it seriously.
Is it correct that in Boipatong it was winter on the 17th of June 1992?
I don't know.  Everybody knows that it is winter around that time.
It was a little cold, but I did not feel it.  I was on duty, I was keeping watch, on the alert.
There were lots of fires burning in Boipatong that night.
I did not go around checking fires at Boipatong.  I would just concentrate on the fire that was lit in my street only.

No, Mr Baloyi, I think you don't understand.  I'm not trying to catch you out, I'm just asking, I would just like some facts.  Normally in winter time there are lots of fires in Boipatong - don't talk about that night specifically, normally in winter time.
Do you mean inside or out in the streets?
What I want to get at, there is a lot of smoke in winter over Boipatong, like Vanderbijlpark likewise.
I think what the witness wants you to do is to clarify the question for him, whether the fires that you're talking about, were they fires in the streets or inside the house.
I mean generally.  The fires inside and outside cause a lot of smoke in Boipatong on a winter evening.
And that affects the sight of people in Boipatong, that you don't see as far and as well as you would on a clear summer night when there is no smoke.
Yes, it does happen from around 7/8, but around 9/10 that smoke will be clear. there will be no smoke.
He is here, he's listening to you as you speak.  I cannot comment on Mr Buwa's statements, no.
Okay, I'll retract that question.  What I want to know from you, did all your neighbours know Mtwana Zulu?
There's not a single person who does not know Mtwana.  He was a good person and he  used to perform with the children.
Did Mr Buwa know him, do you know?
Yes, he knew him very well, he was our neighbour.
Your other neighbour by the name of Victor, did he know Mtwana Zulu?
What I'm saying is, Bafokeng Street, the people of Bafokeng Street, even the people of Boipatong in general know Mtwana.
So if they had seen him there they would have said so?
I would not know about that, I can only comment on what I saw.
Did you hear any shots being fired at the Buwa household?
There was the breaking of windows in Buwa's home.  I was watching, I did not hear any gunshots.  I only heard gunshots at Nxwane's home.
Can you give a reason if there had been shots at Buwa's house, why you wouldn't hear it?  You were watching his house, what is the reason why you would not hear gunshots if it was shot at his house?
But his evidence is that he was watching Buwa's house and all there was was just the sound of breaking windows.  He didn't hear any gunshots sounds.

Mr Chairperson, I would just like then to put the following statement to him.
	Mr Buwa says that he did, there were shots fired at his house, have you any comment on that?
That is his testimony.  What I'm saying is that I did not hear any gunshots.
The people that were walking along Bafokeng Street, were they all carrying loot, goods that they had taken from the houses of the people of Boipatong?

There was a large crowd of people.  I cannot comment whether each and every one of them carried something, but there were many TVs that I saw.  Many of them were carrying items.  I cannot really say if all of them did carry something.
You also saw them carrying it after they had left Bafokeng Street, going over the veld, were they still carrying these goods?
They would not have dumped these items in the township, they did carry them towards the veld.
If somebody goes past you and you have their back towards you, how would you know what happens?
After they had left were there any TVs standing in the veld there?
I did not go to that veld, I was busy with other issues.  The situation was very bad that day, you would not have been able to just go out.  Even policemen were afraid to walk around.

Mr Baloyi, the first time you realised that the people in the black clothes walking along the street with the balaclavas, the first time you thought they were white people was when the white man in the Casspir loaded the body into the Casspir, is that correct?
Yes, I said so.  That is what I said yesterday.
So up to that moment you did not think there were white people taking part in the attack?
I did see the people in the Koyoco and I realised that they were white.

No, I mean the people walking in the street with the black clothes, that you said had balaclavas on.  The people in the Koyoco I'm not talking about, I'm talking about the people on foot.  The first time you thought they might have been white was when the white man wearing the balaclava came to load the body in the Casspir, is that correct?
That is what I said.  Even yesterday I still said the same thing.

So the person saying: "maak gou" didn't really make you think that they were white, you thought it may be a black man that was saying this.  Because it's an expression used by English people, Afrikaans people, Zulu-speaking people, isn't that so?
No, I don't think so.  If an Afrikaner person says: "maak gou", you can understand or you can hear that this is an Afrikaner speaking.
But you just told us that you made the deduction that there were white people involved in the attack when you saw the policeman wearing the balaclava, after the attack.

I said when I heard that voice I recognised that it must have been an Afrikaner and when I saw the person later on who was dressed the same way as those people who had been walking alongside the street, it certainly confirmed that indeed those persons who had been walking along the street on the sidelines were white.
That was not your evidence now, but I'll leave it at that.  Do you speak Afrikaans?
No, I do not know Afrikaans.  I can understand when you talk but I cannot claim that I know Afrikaans.
I am not English but I can understand.

Do you have any description of the man that attacked you in your house?  The lights were switched on, you were trying to keep him out of the room, can you give the Committee any description of that man?
I'm not in a position to describe who they were or what they looked like.  They were in their private clothing.
What kind of clothes did they wear?
No, I do wear glasses sometimes, if maybe I'm reading something, but I don't normally wear them.
Because it's still strange to me that you cannot - can you tell us what clothing this person who attacked you with the axe had on, is it possible for you to tell us that?
What I'm saying is, if you are involved, if you are being attacked you have no time to check what your attacker is wearing.  During fighting you cannot concentrate on a person's clothing.
Do you still maintain that you don't know the colour of the Koyoco that was parked in front of your house?
I do not want to commit to that.  As I said yesterday, Afrikaners are very clever, they respray these vehicles every day.  They would respray them every two days.

But that is not the question, the question is Mr Baloyi, what the colour was when you saw it, not what it was two days later or three days, that   night when you saw it what was the colour of the Koyoco?
I cannot comment on it.  I do not want to commit myself, I just know that it was a Koyoco.
Why did you not go and hide when the attack took place?
They had attacked me.  I would say I could not have hid myself before the attack because they had not yet come to attack me.  I would have expected to hide myself at the time of the attack itself.

Well that's what I also would like to know, why did you not hide yourself because you hid your family, why did you yourself not hide?  You saw them at two of your neighbours and you did not hide, why not?
I am the man of the household, I am the one who was supposed to take care of everything that would be a threat to the safety of my family because I had to protect my family.
Is it not true that you did go and hide?
Because I want to put it to you that my instructions are there were no police taking part in that attack on that night and that your deduction after the attack is wrong.

My instructions are also that Mtwana Zulu was definitely not part of the attack and that you made a mistake when you thought it was him calling the names, because there were many people in that street that knew the children's names.

I have no further questions, thank you, Mr Chairman.
NO FURTHER QUESTIONS BY MS PRETORIUS
Yes, thank you.  Yes, Mr da Silva?

Mr Baloyi, I want to ask you a number of questions to clarify certain aspects.  During the attack or when you saw these vehicles, I understand your evidence  to be that you saw five vehicles in the immediate vicinity of your home, is that correct?

No, he didn't say that in the immediate vicinity.  I think there was one police vehicle in front of his house.  Two went down Umzimvubu and then all the way towards the robots and joined the other two which were at Metal Box.

I accept that, Mr Chairman, I put the question incorrectly.
	Let me ask you this, the vehicle that you saw in front of your house, I understand your evidence to be that it was a police vehicle, is that correct?
It was not an ordinary police vehicle, it was a Koyoco, the one that is used by the police.
Would you agree that your evidence is, and that's how I understand your evidence, that is was a police Koyoco?
Then you saw - did you see a police Koyoco and did you see a police Nyala approaching this police Koyoco in Amatola Street?
No, it went towards Metal Box.  That is what I said.
And the other left Amatola and joined the others so that they became three.  They got off the vehicle and they fired in the air.
Yes.  Just concentrate on the question I'm asking you, Mr Baloyi.

My question was;  the vehicles that he saw in Amatola Street, was that a police Koyoco and was it joined by a police Nyala? 	You've corrected me, Mr Baloyi, the vehicles that you saw near Metal Box, was that a police Koyoco and was that a police Nyala?
Then you saw two further vehicles travelling along Umzimvubu Street, which followed the crowd to the footbridge, were those two police Koyocos, is that what you saw?

Right.  Now apart from the vehicles that you saw in Frikkie Meyer Boulevard, I'm not talking about those vehicles, you only saw police vehicles and you saw no military vehicles in Boipatong township, in the township itself.  Is that your evidence?
No, the military vehicles were parked far away, there were only two of them.  They were near the gate.  I did not see them inside Boipatong.
I understood your evidence yesterday to be that you saw these military vehicles in Frikkie Meyer Boulevard.  You're talking about a gate now, what do you mean by the "gate"?
Let me try and simplify the question.  I understood your evidence to be that the vehicles that you saw in Boipatong were police vehicles, they were not military vehicles, is that correct?
Because my instructions are that there were no military vehicles during the attack in Boipatong, so you must agree with that?
Inside the township really I cannot say,  I only know about my position in Bafokeng Street.
Yes. I'm talking about what you saw.  You saw no military vehicles at any stage during the attack, in Boipatong?

Did you come with the other witnesses this morning in a bus?  I understand - or let me put it more correctly, did you come this morning to this hearing with other people in a bus to this hall, did you travel in a bus?
And I presume you got out of the bus and walked down the path and walked through this door into the hall, is that correct?
Right.  Standing outside in the street were two police vehicles, did you see them?
What type of vehicles are those?
Yes, that's what I hear them say.  I don't know.

Yes.  Now you've testified for two days.  When you went home in the evening, on Tuesday evening and Wednesday evening, did you tell your son, the policeman, either Silo or Pitso, did you tell him: "These people are asking me a lot of questions about the vehicles, please explain to me how these vehicles, what these vehicles are"?  Did you have a conversation along those lines with either of your sons?

I did not.  I just know that these are police vehicles.  I did not ask them the difference between these vehicles because they do not concern me, they are police vehicles.  I just know it is a Koyoco and this is Nyala.  I would have no reason to ask to what model or make or type this is.
Very well.  You explained to the Committee that a Koyoco is bigger than a Casspir, is that correct?
A Casspir is a Koyoco.  The one that is outside here is the smaller one.  I said Koyocos are big and the smallest is Nyala.

Your evidence-in-chief was that
"A Casspir is smaller than a Koyoco"
Are you changing your evidence now?

Look I don't know the names.  They call them Casspirs, they call them Nyala.  I did say that.  The people who know these things are the police.  I suggested to you that you should go and ask my son, he is a police person, a policeman.

Chairperson, with respect, I must object to this cross-examination.  My learned friend has cross-examined this witness to the point where his client is not implicated at all.  There's no point in this further cross-examination I would submit.
Mr Chairman, the version put by my client differs substantially from the version given by this witness.  I'm entitled to cross-examine him, with respect.

I will put my version at the appropriate stage, Mr Chairman.  I submit with respect that I am entitled to test this witness.  The implication of his evidence, Mr Chairman, is that travelling down Nobel Boulevard were three police vehicles, and I've already, or my instructions are that the soldiers never saw these vehicles.  So I'm entitled to test him to see exactly what he saw, Mr Chairman.
And in doing so, please do not cover the ground that we've covered.  He's told us repeatedly what the Nyala is and what he understood the Koyoco to be.
And he has repeatedly said he can't distinguish it, all he knows is that one is smaller and the other one is bigger.

I undertake to be as short as possible.  I know time is of the essence, Mr Chairman.
	Are you saying now, Mr Baloyi, that a Koyoco and a Casspir are one and the same vehicle?
I said to you the police and the soldiers, other ones will know of these names.  What I know is a Koyoco.  It is big and it has a roof door.

But Mr Baloyi, I just want to get clarity.  When you started testifying in your evidence-in-chief, you distinguished between a Koyoco and a Casspir and then you distinguished between a Casspir and an Nyala and I want to know if you know what the difference is between these vehicles.
The one that is parked outside is small and a Koyoco is bigger.
Yes, but do you accept if I tell you that a Casspir and a Koyoco, as known in the township, is one and the same type of vehicle?

I don't know, I saw two Koyocos.  I only saw Nyala when it came to the Metal Box under that tree. That is where they got off and fired shots in the air.  I did not see it inside the township, I only saw it there.

The question is, you differentiated between a Koyoco and a Casspir at a stage.  Your evidence at a stage was that when you looked at Metal Box, you saw two Koyocos and a Casspir joined the two Koyocos.  You changed your evidence under cross-examination.  And what I want to establish is, do you accept that a Koyoco and a Casspir is the same type of vehicle?

I am very sorry,  you see I don't know this word or name "Casspir" because that's where you will trap me, you will me on the name "Casspir".  I just know a Koyoco, a big one and a small one similar to the one that's parked outside.
So can I ask you this, do you know what a Hippo is?  Mr Baloyi, do you know what a Hippo is?
I don't want to tell a lie.  I only know a Koyoco, I call it a Koyoco.
Do you always talk about a Koyoco, don't you use the term Hippo?
We call it Koyoco, even a small child.
The question is, do you not use the term Hippo?
Yes, there are those who use the name Hippo, they know it.  I just hear them talking about Hippo.  I don't know what kind of a vehicle a Hippo is.
Mr Baloyi, do I understand your evidence to be then that when you refer to a large police vehicle, you would use the term Koyoco and you would not use the term Hippo?
I am saying you are the one that is talking about a Hippo, I am talking about a Koyoco.  So you should know the Hippo better, I don't know it.  I only know a Koyoco.
Mr Baloyi, I want to establish what is going on in your mind, I want to establish how you use your terminology and the question is very ...(intervention)
Mr da Silva, the witness has repeatedly told you that he knows this by the name of Koyoco and that is enough.
Mr Chairman, with respect, may I address you, Mr Chairman please?
The terminology of Hippo is going to become very relevant in my further cross-examination, and it is important for me to establish whether this witness uses the term Hippo or not.
He has told you that he uses the name Koyoco.
Let's move onto the next question.

Thank you, Mr Chairman.
	Do you know a suitcase, a vehicle known as a suitcase?
I did say that I saw two of them in Frikkie Meyer Boulevard, not in the township.  They were just parked there.
How do you differentiate between a suitcase and a Koyoco?

They are different, military vehicles are different.  They are vans and they are covered on the side, but you can actually see the heads of the people who are inside, through the roof.  Those are the ones that are called suitcases.  I don't know what you call them.
So you say the one difference is that a suitcase doesn't have a roof and that you can see the soldiers' heads sticking out of the top of the vehicle, is that correct?
Can you explain to the Committee whether there are any other differences that you know of between a suitcase and a Koyoco, apart from the fact ...(intervention)
Look, I've never been to the army, I've never been to an army camp so I cannot talk about army vehicles.

So you say that when you were standing at your house - you must correct me if I'm wrong, you're standing on your lawn or in front of your house and you're looking across the veld towards Frikkie Meyer Boulevard and you saw two suitcases.  Is that your evidence?
You say that at a distance of 350 metres, whilst standing in front of your house, you could distinguish two military vehicles in Frikkie Meyer Boulevard?

They were not moving, they were stationary.  I said so.  I don't know what they were doing there.  They were just stationary, they did not move.  The only ones that were moving were the Koyocos, the ones that were running or moving through Umzimvubu Street.
